we can break if you want.. i'm still curious about some scenarios on how you'd handle it

$300 may seem small, but that shit adds up fast; the way you make money in consulting/contracting is billable hours; so theoretically I could "just work saturday" for 4 hours to cover the costs, but screw that; I want to play on Saturday
rarely does my contractrs/invoices have ANYTHING other than hours worked on it (sometimes taxis, flights, hotels, and food)
If you put on contract, yes, if you don't, no, hehe
The point here is hardware and software adds up to a lot. It's better to be taxed as "I made $80k this year" vs. "I made $90k this year"
Those W2's who pay $7 a month for GIT I guarentee most don't tell the IRS NOT to tax them on the $84 bucks they spent

yeah, i get all that.. makes sense... i guess i wasn't thinking right about the "i buy x for $y, and charge client $y+$z, THEN write it off"... just didn't seem right, but i suppose since there's a paper trail all along the way, it makes sense to have to write it off so you're not charged twice like you said
Your employer eats a lot, but still, when you're buying iPhone developer fee's and Git hub subscriptions... it's just not fair to be taxed twice on that.

yeah... i'm in a good spot regarding all that

Do yourself a favor if you're not that into it: Go see your nearest Edward Jones office. They'll tell you what to do. If you can't even do that, take 10% of your paycheck, and put in a savings account you can't touch, like a CD. That said, I still say Edward Jones is the better choice unless you are actually into finances.

401k's are good if you have an employer who matches. IRA's and Roth IRA's are good because that's about 4k a year the gov't can't touch. SEP IRA's are the shit, but you have to part with a lot of money; most contractors/small biz' can't do too much of htat

but yeah, for w2 we try to use tax shelters like 401k's n such

The value of the money you put in is inversely proportional to your age. The younger you are, the MORE valueable your money. The sooner you do it, the better off you'll be.
